summary: This is a December 6, 2018 internal update from the Public Corruption Unit, likely within the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (SDNY). It outlines the significant development of a new investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's alleged sexual abuse of minors, focusing on conduct that occurred in or involved New York, and explicitly questioning the scope and effect of the 2008 Florida Non-Prosecution Agreement.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of the new federal investigation for allegedly sexually abusing dozens of minors over more than a decade, including those transported to/from New York. Previously resolved a 2008 federal investigation in Florida with a Non-Prosecution Agreement.

events.title: Florida Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) Resolution
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein resolved a then-pending federal investigation by the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida by entering into a Non-Prosecution Agreement. The NPA purported to immunize Epstein and alleged co-conspirators, including a New York-based 'booker'.

events.title: SDNY Public Corruption Unit Update on Epstein Investigation
events.description: The Public Corruption Unit reports it is actively investigating allegations that Jeffrey Epstein sexually abused dozens of minors over more than a decade, with a focus on New York-based victims and conduct. The investigation is reviewing documents from the original Florida probe and planning to look into post-NPA misconduct.

keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office, with the FBI, opened a new investigation into Jeffrey Epstein for allegedly sexually abusing dozens of minors over a decade or more, specifically focusing on victims based in or transported to/from New York.

The document explicitly notes the 2008 Florida Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) was 'by its terms binding only' the Southern District of Florida, implying the SDNY does not consider itself bound by it.

The Florida NPA is stated to have immunized not just Epstein, but also 'a number of his alleged co-conspirators,' including a New York-based 'booker' responsible for scheduling 'massages' with underage girls.
The investigation is actively identifying New York-based victims and plans to investigate allegations of misconduct that occurred after the 2008 Florida NPA was signed.
The document is an internal government update, indicating the investigation was active and a significant priority for the Public Corruption Unit as of December 2018.
